Expectation1: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation1: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I was sitting in the church office, preparing for Sunday’s youth group lesson on honesty and integrity, when my phone buzzed. It was a text from my activist group: “A legislative aide is free to talk about the bill—call now!” My heart raced. This was the moment we’d been waiting for, a chance to push for real change. But I glanced at the Bible open on my desk, the lesson on truthfulness staring back at me. I knew the bill’s details inside out, but I also knew that some of our talking points stretched the truth, painting the opposition in a harsher light than they deserved. As a Christian, I felt the weight of my commitment to honesty and loving my neighbor, even those I disagreed with. As an activist, I felt the pressure to seize this rare opportunity, to do whatever it took to persuade the aide. My hands trembled as I stared at my phone, torn between the call I needed to make and the values I was supposed to uphold.
